>> A couple years ago back when I was in
high school, I really wanted to study
STEM in university and possibly for a
future career. However, it seemed quite
scary and intimidating. In fact, my team
and I have interviewed quite a few high
school students who say the same things.
other it's really hard. You already have
to be a genius before you get in. There
are stigmas around demographics that can
and cannot study STEM. There isn't much
of an opportunity to get into the
industry and that there is nobody alive
this century that they can look up to as
a role model. There is also an
Australian government report that
highlights this. A lot of high school
students cannot see themselves in a
future career involving STEM. Labs is a
platform that gives high schoolers
access to the reality of science,
bridging the gap between high school and
the real world of STEM. To do this,
LabSoft provides a platform for high
schoolers to access educational content
from real experts, to access
opportunities like internships and
conferences, and to join a community
comprising secondary, tertiary, and
postgraduate members. It does this by
creating a platform for science
communicators to upload educational
content and plug their own personal
channels. It showcases the applications
of STEM in the workforce and in
academia. All the while focusing on the
personal journeys of experts and PhD
students to humanize what it means to be
a STEM worker. From the homepage, you
can log into three different types of
accounts. A personal account, a student
account, or a teacher account. If you
log into a student account, you will see
the experiment you last viewed, any
experiments your teacher has assigned to
you, as well as the latest featured
events. Experiments are categorized in
discipline. Clicking on to an experiment
will bring you to the experiment page.
>> Each experiment has two associated
videos, a how-to video and a background
video. The how-to video is where our
content creators shine. They make
personalized content for students to
follow through an experiment and gain an
understanding of what they'll be
learning. The background video gives
broader context to this experiment. This
is where students understand the
applications of what they're learning in
the workforce and in academia.
>> There are also additional content that
you can access through buttons. You can
access additional worksheets via PDF as
well as social links to the mentor who
has created the experiment to create a
sense of community if you have any
questions or if you want to view any of
the work that they've done additionally.
Lastly, there is also an events module.
Here will bring you to the list of
events. This may be lectures, workshops,
excursions or any other opportunities
for students or the general public. Part
of the reason we really wanted to have
livestock is primarily a smartphone
application is because phones these days
have a whole lot of sensors that we can
gather some really cool data from.
Things like gyroscopes and microphones
that typically would have to be used
with really expensive lab equipment are
now a whole lot more accessible and we
can tap into through the phones. On top
of this, we're looking into utilizing
augmented reality to have the
instructors in the same room as the
person who's doing the experiment. What
this helps do is increase engagement and
really foster that connection between
instructor and student. As the
Australian government's STEM equity
monitor shows, as students progress
through school, their interest and
confidence in STEM subjects drops off,
and they're not as keen to follow a STEM
career as they once were. Other studies
have proposed solutions that aren't
necessarily being tapped into at the
moment, such as increasing the number of
role models that students can identify
with or helping students see themselves
as scientists. These have been shown to
increase the likelihood of extended
interest, but only if they're done over
an extended period of time rather than
in sporadic once offs, which is why we
want Labsock to be easily accessible in
the classroom. Labs hopes to fill a
niche in educational programs that has
not been explored before. All programs
such as Chan Academy and Adollo focus on
worked out examples. Labs hopes to focus
more on fostering a sense of community
and also providing physical experiments.
Goal of this is not to work through
problems but rather to inspire students
to study STEM in the future. We hope to
gain revenue on lab by two main avenues.
The first is by integrating classroom
packages which allow schools for a fee
to give their teachers teacher accounts
that are attached to a virtual
classroom. This will allow them to match
content on labs to their lesson plans.
We also give them access to 24/7 online
support. Secondly, we hope to allow
selected organizations to list STEM
related events and internships on our
platform. This will hopefully inspire
students and show them the link between
studying STEM and what their future
career can be.

Hello, my name is Jordan and today I'm
going to be presenting my team's design
concept submission for the design for
change 2021 challenge. We've created
this project as part of a technology
design unit. I'll quickly introduce the
members of the team for this project.
Firstly, Sver, our project principal and
facilitator, Emily and Shan who
contributed the bulk of the conceptual
aspects of this project, myself, Jordan,
Marius, and Michael. The core principle
and value of insurance Australia group
that we chose to align ourselves with is
diversity, inclusion, and belonging.
This was something that felt natural for
us to tap into. Having a somewhat gender
diverse group in a usually
male-dominated course. What we found
here was an incredibly complex web of
interconnected gender equality issues
resulting in women not only finding
themselves underrepresented in STEM but
finding it more difficult to get
involved or even just to stay involved.
The complex nature of these issues,
although daunting at first, helped us to
define the scope of our project to what
we could realistically affect with just
an application. Our vision developed
into wanting to help young girls connect
with like-minded peers, particularly
mentors and role model figures. This
meant that we needed to design a system
that could help connect young girls and
women with those like-minded peers, role
models, and learning resources that will
be better focused towards them. Upon
preliminary research of this interest
area, we found a few apps that could do
similar things. Mentor loop and women in
STEM provided a similar connection tool,
while LinkedIn could provide similar
kinds of access to successful career
women. And STEM tutoring provides a
direct mentor to mentee connection
service.
When we decided how we were going to
differentiate ourselves, we looked at
providing a fun, more gamified
experience. What we found with a lot of
current offerings in this space was that
very few of them were targeted towards
younger school girls and we wanted to
fill this space. We created an app with
girls aged 10 to 15 in mind mainly.
Although we expect this to easily extend
a few years beyond those two limits.
Initially we went where we to implement
this design. We would be approaching
schools to help us populate the app. We
also need to approach some established
women in STEM who are eager to get
involved in a cause such as this. I'm
going to quickly demonstrate a few key
features of our prototype we've created
with Adobe XD. This is our landing page
where we've created islands that each
represent an area of STEM. When we click
on an island, we see a procedurally
generated view which is selected by
users interests and activity levels.
Here a user can browse between their
young peers who are interested in
pursuing STEM. We've named those little
sisters. They can find mentors that they
can connect with known as big sisters
and they can browse and get involved in
interest groups known as villages.
Obviously, approaching people that
you've never met can be a little
daunting. So each day the app selects a
sister of the day who's promoted based
on a few performance metrics such as
their level which is based on their
activity, the amount of little sisters
they've been recommended by and the
total little sisters that they've
connected with and assisted.
So a few hidden ones like their average
response times to new messages or how
many little sisters they are currently
messaging.
Future like this is critical to
encourage prospective young women in
STEM to take the first steps in
developing a network and finding people
that they can be encouraged by or
inspired by. Member of the app can send
a request to join a group which they'll
need to be approved by the group's
leader or admin.
Any village that has been joined is then
accessible by the option my villages in
the menu.
The villages use a unique design
language to portray the sections of the
group and provide a unique flavor to the
app's experience. For example, the town
hall can be used to make announcements.
The library can use to create or upload
documents. And the theater can be used
for communicating over integrated voice
chat or video chat. There are a few
other features that our prototype has,
but for the sake of brevity, I hope that
this small look has demonstrated some of
the key design concepts that are behind
our application.
The desired impact of this application
is to empower young girls by connecting
them to role models, tackling some of
the stereotypes that are typically
associated with STEM fields, to give
families tools to help their young women
succeed, and to deliver a platform where
students and professionals alike can
share their experiences and grow
alongside one another. We think this
idea is pretty malleable, so we've got a
few ideas for how it could be developed
further. These are some of them, though
among the most important are ensuring
that the platform is properly moderated.
Given the precautious age that this
design targets, this is an area where we
would expect to be constantly iterating
and improving.
That's all for the presentation. We hope

>> Hi everyone and welcome to our
presentation for the leader automated
composting system and mobile app. My
name is Thomas and I'm the team leader
for this project. In the team we have
Lachlan and Jeremy who are experts in
mobile app development. Dominic who is
experienced with data management and
Nicholas our IoT hardware technician.
This project was proposed by our client
Alex James Castillo who conducted a
thesis on the microbial ecology of urban
organic waste treatment or compost as we
know it.
Did you know that in Australia around
80% of our organic waste ends up in
landfill creating greenhouse emissions
that could have been easily avoided if
more households were actively
composting. By diverting organic waste
from landfill, we can reduce the strain
on the environment in terms of the 13
million tons of CO2 that is created per
year as a result of organic waste going
to landfill. Working closely with
Swimburn Researchers, we're creating
Leader, a better way to compost and make
use of organic waste. Leader is an
automatic composting system designed to
produce highquality compost by providing
a controlled environment for the process
to take place. Accompanying the
composter is a mobile app that will
provide useful information to the user
via the output of several sensors inside
a device, allowing the user to monitor
and pause the system at any time. By
working closely with our client, our
team was able to gain a proper
understanding of the vision behind
leader, allowing us to begin the design
process with the client's objective in
mind. To achieve this objective, we have
designed a Raspberry Pi IoT system to
automate the composter prototype and
provide data for our app. To ensure a
smooth and flexible development process,
we will be utilizing tools such as
GitHub for version control, Jira for
task management, and Confluence for
documentation and apply them to our
agile canban methodology. After
conducting extensive research, our team
decided to utilize a REST API to
separate these objectives across backend
and front-end services.
Our backend will provide the interface
we need for communication and data
transfer between the Raspberry Pi IoT
system, our Firebase data store and also
our front-end service. The front end
will provide the platform on which the
mobile app can operate with the app
itself being created using React Native
for Android and iOS devices along with
several other APIs to support optimal
performance and testing functionality.
The leader system carefully controls the
environment by mixing and air rating the
waste daily. It will also regulate the
temperature and air flow via the use of
air pumps, creating the ideal
environment for food composting microbes
to thrive. Data such as temperature,
oxygen levels, and moisture levels will
be collected and used as parameters to
enforce this controlled environment. The
leader system will know when organic
waste has been deposited via an infrared
sensor trigger and begin the monitoring
process. Throughout the composting life
cycle, the user will be able to monitor
the decomposition process via a
graphical display of the sensor
information. Logs will also be recorded
whenever the compost is stirred or
whenever food is deposited to give the
user the peace of mind that the system
is operating correctly. We have begun
the development stage and have
initialize our hardware components as
well as our backend and front-end
services.
Other similar solutions speed up the
composting process by applying heat,
producing lower quality compost that is
sometimes harmful to plants. Leader,
however, ensures a high quality compost
that is perfect for use in any garden.
In Australia, households contribute to
75% of the food that is sent to
landfill. To solve this issue, leader is
designed to become a staple for
households in Australia. However, we
believe Lader can be adapted to be
incorporated into small businesses like
restaurants and cafes as well as large
office complexes.
We feel that leader aligns with IG's
vision to become a more sustainable
business over the long term. Our team is
confident that our leader prototype can
provide users with an easier way to
dispose of their organic waste and in
turn create higher quality compost while
reducing their contribution to landfill.
